paragraph: Olivier Panis (born 1966) is a retired French Formula 1 driver who competed in 158 Grands Prix from 1994 to 2004 for teams such as Ligier, Prost, and BAR. He achieved five podium finishes, including a memorable victory at the 1996 Monaco Grand Prix, driving a wet-weather masterpiece. Panis was known for his consistency and ability to extract the maximum from his machinery, and later became a test driver for Toyota.

name: Onofre Marimón
paragraph: Onofre Marimón (1923 – 1954) was an Argentine Formula One driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix from 1951 to 1954. He secured two podium finishes, including a third place at the 1953 Belgian Grand Prix, scoring 8.14 championship points. Tragically, Marimón's life was cut short in a practice crash at the 1954 German Grand Prix. He was known for his talent and enthusiasm, leaving a lasting impression on the F1 community.

name: Oscar Alfredo Gálvez
paragraph: Oscar Alfredo Gálvez (1913 – 1989) was an Argentine racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1953 Argentine Grand Prix, driving a Maserati. He finished fifth in that race, scoring 2 championship points. Gálvez is best known for his extensive and highly successful career in Turismo Carretera (TC), a popular Argentine stock car racing series, where he was a national icon.

name: Óscar González
paragraph: Óscar González (1923 – 2006) was a Uruguayan Formula One driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1956 Argentine Grand Prix, where he shared a Maserati with Alberto Uria and finished sixth, scoring no points. He also competed in other non-championship F1 races. González's brief F1 career highlighted his involvement in South American motorsport, but he remains a relatively obscure figure in F1 history.

name: Oscar Larrauri
paragraph: Oscar Larrauri (born 1954) is a retired Argentine racing driver who competed in 21 Formula One Grands Prix from 1988 to 1989 for the EuroBrun team. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 13th. Despite his limited success in F1, he achieved success in other racing series, most notably in the World Sportscar Championship, where he was a race winner with Brun Motorsport.

name: Oscar Piastri
paragraph: Oscar Piastri (born 2001) is an Australian Formula 1 driver who currently competes for McLaren. He made his Formula 1 debut in 2023 and has quickly established himself as a talented and competitive driver. Piastri has secured multiple podium finishes and a sprint race victory. Prior to joining F1, he won the Formula 2 (2021) and Formula 3 (2020) championships in consecutive rookie seasons, showcasing his impressive skills and speed.

name: Oswald Karch
paragraph: Oswald Karch (1917 – 2009) was a German Formula One driver who participated in a single Grand Prix, the 1953 German Grand Prix, driving a Veritas. He finished 12th in that race, albeit several laps behind the leader, and did not score any championship points. Karch's brief F1 outing was a relatively rare appearance for a driver from Germany in the early 1950s.

name: Otto Stuppacher
paragraph: Otto Stuppacher (1940 – 2001) was an Austrian former Formula 1 driver who attempted to qualify for three Grands Prix in 1976 with the Tyrrell and Ensign teams. He failed to qualify for any of the events he entered, and therefore made no Grand Prix starts. Stuppacher's F1 career was marked by a lack of success and remains a relatively obscure footnote in the history of the championship.

name: Ottorino Volonterio
paragraph: Ottorino Volonterio (1917 – 2003) was a Swiss Formula One driver who competed in three Grands Prix between 1954 and 1957. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 11th. Volonterio also competed in non-championship Formula One events and various sports car races. He passed away on March 10, 2003.

name: Pablo Birger
paragraph: Pablo Birger (1924 – 1966) was an Argentine racing driver who competed in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, both the Argentine Grand Prix (1953 and 1955). He retired from both races and did not score any championship points. Birger's F1 appearances were limited, and he was primarily active in local Argentinian racing series. He passed away on March 9, 1966.

name: Paco Godia
paragraph: Francisco "Paco" Godia Sales (1921 – 1990) was a Spanish Formula One driver who competed in 14 Grands Prix from 1954 to 1958, primarily for Maserati. He scored a total of 6 championship points and achieved two fourth-place finishes. Godia was known for his speed and bravery on the track and remained a respected figure in the F1 paddock during his active years, often competing with private entries.

name: Paddy Driver
paragraph: Paddy Driver (born 1934) is a former South African Formula One driver who competed in one Grand Prix, the 1963 South African Grand Prix, where he finished 11th and scored no points. He is more famously known for his participation and success in motorcycle racing, including the Grand Prix motorcycle racing circuit. Driver also competed in the South African Formula One championship with greater success than in the World Championship.

name: Paolo Barilla
paragraph: Paolo Barilla (born 1961) is a former Italian Formula One driver who competed in 15 Grands Prix from 1989 to 1990 for the Minardi team. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 10th. Barilla, part of the famous Barilla food company family, was relatively inexperienced during his F1 tenure. He later achieved success in endurance racing, winning the 1985 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Pascal Fabre
paragraph: Pascal Fabre (born 1960) is a French former racing driver who participated in 14 Formula 1 World Championship Grands Prix, all with the AGS team, in 1987. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of ninth. Fabre's F1 career was marked by struggles with the uncompetitive AGS car, but he showed promise in other racing series, including Formula 3000. Fabre is now largely retired from professional racing.

name: Pascal Wehrlein
paragraph: Pascal Wehrlein (born 1994) is a German-Mauritian Formula 1 driver who competed in 39 Grands Prix from 2016 to 2017 for Manor Racing and Sauber. He scored 6 championship points, with a best finish of eighth at the 2017 Spanish Grand Prix. Wehrlein has shown impressive speed and consistency throughout his F1 career and later achieved success in Formula E, winning the 2023 Mexico City E-Prix. He is currently a factory driver for Porsche in Formula E.

name: Pastor Maldonado
paragraph: Pastor Maldonado (born 1985) is a Venezuelan former Formula 1 driver who competed in 96 Grands Prix from 2011 to 2015 for the Williams and Lotus teams. He is known for his aggressive driving style and his sole F1 win at the 2012 Spanish Grand Prix. Maldonado was also infamous for being involved in several crashes and incidents on the track. He scored 68 championship points during his F1 career.

name: Pat Flaherty
paragraph: Pat Flaherty (1926 – 2002) was an American racing driver who competed in seven Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 from 1950 to 1956. He won the 1956 Indianapolis 500, scoring 8 championship points. Flaherty's IndyCar career is most notable for this victory, making him one of the few drivers to win an F1-counted Indy 500.

name: Pat O'Connor
paragraph: Pat O'Connor (1928 – 1958) was an American racing driver who competed in five Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 from 1954 to 1958. He scored 4 championship points, with a best finish of eighth. Tragically, O'Connor's life was cut short in a multi-car crash during the first lap of the 1958 Indianapolis 500. He was a talented IndyCar driver who achieved several top-ten finishes.

name: Patricio O'Ward
paragraph: Patricio "Pato" O'Ward (born 1999) is a Mexican professional racing driver currently competing in the IndyCar Series. He has participated in several Formula 1 free practice sessions for McLaren as a test and reserve driver since 2021, but has not made a Grand Prix start. O'Ward has achieved significant success in IndyCar, winning multiple races, and is considered one of the rising stars in open-wheel racing, with aspirations for an F1 race seat.

name: Patrick Depailler
paragraph: Patrick Depailler (1944 – 1980) was a French Formula 1 driver known for his exceptional talent and competitive spirit. He competed in 95 Grands Prix from 1972 to 1980 for teams like Tyrrell, Ligier, and Alfa Romeo. Depailler achieved two Grand Prix victories and 19 podium finishes, scoring 141 championship points. Considered one of the top drivers of his era, his life was tragically cut short in a testing accident in 1980.

name: Patrick Friesacher
paragraph: Patrick Friesacher (born 1980) is a retired Austrian Formula One driver who competed in 11 Grands Prix during the 2005 season for Minardi. He scored 3 championship points with a sixth-place finish at the 2005 United States Grand Prix. Friesacher's F1 career was cut short due to reliability issues and a lack of competitiveness, leading to his mid-season replacement. Prior to F1, he was a successful junior driver, winning the 2003 International Formula 3000 championship.

name: Patrick Gaillard
paragraph: Patrick Gaillard (born 1952) is a French former racing driver who competed in 5 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix during the 1979 season for Ensign. He failed to qualify for three of his entries and did not score any championship points, with a best finish of 13th at the 1979 British Grand Prix. His F1 career was short-lived, and he later competed in sports car racing.

name: Patrick Nève
paragraph: Patrick Nève (1949 – 2017) was a Belgian Formula 1 driver who competed in 10 Grands Prix in 1976 and 1977 for Ensign and his own Patrick Nève team. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th at the 1977 Italian Grand Prix. Nève often struggled to qualify for races due to uncompetitive machinery. Despite limited success, he remained a determined competitor during his brief F1 career.

name: Patrick Tambay
paragraph: Patrick Tambay (1949 – 2022) was a French Formula 1 driver who competed from 1977 to 1986, making 114 Grand Prix starts. He achieved two Grand Prix victories and 11 podium finishes, driving for teams such as McLaren, Ferrari, and Renault. Known for his speed and charismatic personality, Tambay was a popular figure in the F1 paddock, particularly after his poignant win for Ferrari at the 1983 San Marino Grand Prix, following the death of his friend and teammate Gilles Villeneuve.

name: Paul Belmondo
paragraph: Paul Belmondo (born 1963) is a French former racing driver who competed in 27 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1992 and 1994 for March and Pacific. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 9th at the 1992 Hungarian Grand Prix. The son of actor Jean-Paul Belmondo, his F1 career was short and largely uncompetitive. He later founded his own sports car racing team.

name: Paul di Resta
paragraph: Paul di Resta (born 1986) is a Scottish former Formula 1 driver who competed in 59 Grands Prix from 2011 to 2013, and a single race in 2017, for Force India and Williams. He scored 121 championship points, with a best finish of 4th at the 2012 Singapore Grand Prix. Known for his consistent speed, di Resta made a notable impact in F1. He later transitioned to endurance racing and is a respected F1 commentator.

name: Paul Emery
paragraph: Paul Emery (1916 – 1993) was a British Formula One driver who participated in 2 World Championship Grands Prix in 1956 and 1957, failing to finish either race and scoring no points. He also attempted two other Grand Prix entries without starting. Emery's racing career was marked by limited success in F1, but he was a pioneer in the development of the Emeryson racing car, primarily in national events.

name: Paul England
paragraph: Paul England (1929 – 2014) was an Australian Formula One driver who competed in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1957 German Grand Prix, driving a Cooper. He finished 12th in that race and did not score any championship points. England's F1 career was very brief, but he did achieve some success in other forms of motorsport in Australia and Europe.

name: Paul Frère
paragraph: Paul Frère (1917 – 2008) was a Belgian racing driver who competed in 11 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1952 to 1956. He achieved one podium finish, a second place at the 1956 Belgian Grand Prix, scoring 11 championship points. Frère was also highly successful in endurance racing, winning the 1960 24 Hours of Le Mans. After retiring from racing, he became a respected automotive journalist.

name: Paul Goldsmith
paragraph: Paul Goldsmith (born 1925) is a former American professional racing driver. He competed in 6 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1958 and 1961. He scored 6 championship points, with a best finish of 3rd at the 1959 Indianapolis 500. Goldsmith is more notable for his highly successful career in NASCAR, winning nine races and finishing second in the 1961 championship.

name: Paul Hawkins
paragraph: Paul Hawkins (1937 – 1969) was an Australian Formula 1 driver who competed in 3 Grands Prix in 1965 for Brabham. He scored no championship points. Hawkins is best known for his daring driving, including famously crashing into the Monaco harbour during the 1965 Grand Prix. He was a skilled and versatile driver in sports cars and touring cars. Tragically, he lost his life in a crash during a non-championship Formula 2 race at Oulton Park in 1969.

name: Paul Pietsch
paragraph: Paul Pietsch (1911 – 2012) was a German Formula One driver who competed in 3 Grands Prix between 1950 and 1952 for Alfa Romeo and Veritas. He scored 2 championship points with a third-place finish at the 1950 German Grand Prix. Pietsch was notable for being one of the oldest F1 drivers at the time of his participation, competing into his forties. He passed away at the age of 100, one of F1's longest-lived drivers.

name: Paul Russo
paragraph: Paul Russo (1914 – 1976) was an American racing driver who competed in 14 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 (1950-1960 and 1962). He achieved a best finish of 2nd at the 1955 Indianapolis 500, scoring a total of 12.5 championship points. Russo was a versatile driver who also competed successfully in sprint cars and midgets, before the Indy 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship.

name: Pedro Chaves
paragraph: Pedro Chaves (born 1965) is a Portuguese former racing driver who competed in 13 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix for the Coloni team during the 1991 season. He failed to pre-qualify for every race he entered, and therefore made no Grand Prix starts, scoring no championship points. Chaves previously showed promise in Formula 3000 but his F1 career was marred by uncompetitive machinery. He continued to compete in other racing series, notably sports cars, after F1.

name: Pedro de la Rosa
paragraph: Pedro de la Rosa (born 1971) is a Spanish former Formula One driver who competed in 104 Grands Prix from 1999 to 2012 for teams like Arrows, Jaguar, McLaren, Sauber, and HRT. He scored 35 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a second place at the 2006 Hungarian Grand Prix. De la Rosa is widely known for his extensive and valuable test and reserve driver roles with McLaren and Ferrari, playing a key part in car development.

name: Pedro Diniz
paragraph: Pedro Diniz (born 1970) is a Brazilian former Formula 1 driver who competed in 98 Grands Prix from 1995 to 2000 for Forti, Ligier, Arrows, and Sauber. He scored a total of 10 championship points, with a best finish of 5th. Diniz's career was notably driven by significant sponsorship from his wealthy family. Despite never achieving a podium, he was a familiar face in the F1 paddock during the late 1990s.

name: Pedro Lamy
paragraph: Pedro Lamy (born 1972) is a Portuguese former Formula 1 driver who competed in 32 Grands Prix from 1993 to 1996 for Lotus and Minardi. He scored one championship point with a sixth-place finish at the 1996 Australian Grand Prix. Lamy is more renowned for his endurance racing successes, including winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in the GT2 class in 1998 and multiple championships in the FIA World Endurance Championship.

name: Pedro Rodríguez
paragraph: Pedro Rodríguez (1940 – 1971) was a Mexican Formula 1 driver who competed in 54 Grands Prix from 1963 to 1971. He achieved two Grand Prix victories and seven podium finishes, scoring 64 championship points. Rodríguez was renowned for his exceptional speed and daring driving skills in both F1 (for Ferrari and BRM) and endurance racing, winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1968. Tragically, his life was cut short in a sports car racing accident at the age of 31.

name: Perry McCarthy
paragraph: Perry McCarthy (born 1961) is a British former racing driver who attempted to qualify for 10 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix for the Andrea Moda team in 1992. He famously failed to pre-qualify or qualify for any race, becoming known for the team's chronic uncompetitiveness. Despite his limited F1 opportunities, McCarthy has remained involved in the sport as a commentator and humorist, often recounting his unusual F1 experiences.

name: Pete Lovely
paragraph: Pete Lovely (1926 – 2011) was an American racing driver who participated in 5 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1959 and 1969, scoring no points. He is best known for driving his own privately entered Lotus cars, often transporting them himself. Lovely was a passionate privateer who competed in various forms of motorsport, particularly sports car racing, before and after his brief F1 forays.

name: Peter Arundell
paragraph: Peter Arundell (1933 – 2009) was a British former racing driver who competed in 13 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1964 and 1966 for Team Lotus. He scored 11 championship points and achieved two podium finishes, both in his rookie 1964 season. Arundell's promising F1 career was sadly cut short by a serious Formula 2 crash and persistent health issues, preventing him from reaching his full potential.

name: Peter Ashdown
paragraph: Peter Ashdown (born 1934) is a British former racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1959 British Grand Prix, in a Cooper-Climax, finishing 12th. He did not score any championship points. Ashdown also competed in several non-championship Formula 1 events and was more widely known for his success in sports car racing.

name: Peter Broeker
paragraph: Peter Broeker (1929 – 1980) was a Canadian Formula One driver who competed in one Grand Prix, the 1963 United States Grand Prix, driving a Stebro, a car he owned and which was a rare Canadian F1 entry. He finished 7th in that race, failing to score any championship points. Broeker's participation in F1 was largely limited to this unique home appearance, but he remains a notable figure in Canadian motorsport history for his dedication.

name: Peter Collins
paragraph: Peter Collins (1931 – 1958) was a British Formula 1 driver who competed in 33 Grands Prix from 1952 to 1958. He achieved three Grand Prix victories and nine podium finishes, scoring 47 championship points. Collins drove for teams such as HWM and Ferrari and was considered one of the top drivers of his era. Tragically, his life was cut short in a crash at the 1958 German Grand Prix while leading the race.

name: Peter de Klerk
paragraph: Peter de Klerk (1935 – 2015) was a South African Formula One driver who competed in 4 World Championship Grands Prix (all South African Grands Prix) between 1963 and 1969. He scored 1 championship point with a 10th place at the 1965 South African Grand Prix. De Klerk was known for driving his own LDS Formula One cars. He was also a successful driver in non-championship Formula One events.

name: Peter Hirt
paragraph: Peter Hirt (1910 – 1992) was a Swiss Formula One driver who competed in 5 Grands Prix from 1951 to 1953 for Ferrari and Veritas. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th at the 1952 Swiss Grand Prix. Hirt primarily competed with his own Écurie Espadon team, marking a brief appearance in the early years of F1.

name: Peter Gethin
paragraph: Peter Gethin (1940 – 2011) was a British Formula 1 driver who competed in 30 Grands Prix from 1970 to 1974. He famously won the 1971 Italian Grand Prix, the closest finish in F1 history, beating Ronnie Peterson by just 0.01 seconds. Gethin drove for teams including McLaren, BRM, and Embassy Hill, scoring 11 championship points. He was known for his aggressive driving style and versatility in various racing categories.

name: Peter Revson
paragraph: Peter Revson (1939 – 1974) was an American Formula One driver who competed in 30 Grands Prix from 1964 to 1974. He achieved two Grand Prix wins (1973 British and Canadian Grands Prix) and eight podium finishes, scoring 61 championship points for McLaren. Born into a wealthy family, Revson's F1 career showed flashes of brilliance but was tragically cut short by a fatal crash during testing at Kyalami, South Africa, in 1974.

name: Peter Ryan
paragraph: Peter Ryan (1940 – 1962) was a Canadian racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1961 United States Grand Prix, in a Lotus, finishing 9th. He did not score any championship points. Ryan was a promising young driver whose career was tragically cut short when he was killed in a crash during the 1962 Formula Libre race at the Reims-Gueux circuit in France.

name: Peter Walker
paragraph: Peter Walker (1912 – 1984) was a British racing driver who competed in 4 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1950 and 1955, primarily for his own privateer entries. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th at the 1951 British Grand Prix. Walker is also remembered for his success in sports car racing, including winning the 1951 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Peter Westbury
paragraph: Peter Westbury (1938 – 2015) was a British racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1969 German Grand Prix, driving a Brabham. He failed to score any championship points. Westbury was more successful in other formulas, winning the 1969 European Formula 2 Championship. His F1 appearance was his only World Championship start.

name: Peter Whitehead
paragraph: Peter Whitehead (1914 – 1958) was a British Formula 1 driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix from 1950 to 1954. He scored a total of 4 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1950 French Grand Prix. Whitehead was known for often racing his own privately entered Ferrari 125, making him a notable privateer in the early years of the World Championship. He tragically died in a sports car race in 1958.

name: Phil Cade
paragraph: Phil Cade (1916 – 2001) was an American racing driver who entered one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1959 United States Grand Prix, but failed to qualify. He was primarily known for his involvement in sports car racing. Cade's F1 attempt was brief and unsuccessful, with his efforts concentrated on national level competitions rather than the top tier of international single-seater racing.

name: Phil Hill
paragraph: Phil Hill (1927 – 2008) was an American Formula One driver who became the first American to win the World Drivers' Championship in 1961. He competed in 48 Grands Prix from 1958 to 1966, achieving three Grand Prix wins and 16 podium finishes, scoring 94 championship points. Hill drove primarily for Ferrari and was known for his smooth driving style and technical feedback. He also had a highly successful career in endurance racing, winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans three times.

name: Philip Fotheringham-Parker
paragraph: Philip Fotheringham-Parker (1907 – 1981) was a British racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1951 British Grand Prix, driving a non-works ERA. He finished 11th in that race and did not score any points. His F1 career was brief and limited to this single appearance, making him a less prominent figure in F1 history.

name: Philippe Adams
paragraph: Philippe Adams (born 1969) is a Belgian former racing driver who made two brief appearances in Formula One in 1994 for the Lotus team. He qualified for both the Belgian and Portuguese Grands Prix, but retired from both races and failed to score any points. His Formula One career was short-lived, and he returned to competing in lower formulae and sports car racing after his stint with Lotus.

name: Philippe Alliot
paragraph: Philippe Alliot (born 1954) is a French former Formula 1 driver who competed in 109 Grands Prix from 1984 to 1990, and a single race in 1994. He drove for teams like RAM, Ligier, Larrousse, and McLaren, scoring 7 championship points, with a best finish of 5th. Alliot was known for his tenacious driving, though his F1 career was often hampered by uncompetitive machinery. He later raced in sports cars, including Le Mans.

name: Philippe Étancelin
paragraph: Philippe Étancelin (1896 – 1981) was a French Formula One driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix between 1950 and 1952. He achieved one podium finish, a 5th place (shared) at the 1950 Italian Grand Prix, scoring 3 championship points. Étancelin was known for his longevity as a racing driver, having started competing in the 1920s and making him one of the oldest drivers to participate in the early F1 World Championship.

name: Philippe Streiff
paragraph: Philippe Streiff (1955 – 2022) was a French Formula One driver who competed in 53 Grands Prix from 1984 to 1988 for teams like Renault, Ligier, Tyrrell, and AGS. He scored 11 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1985 Australian Grand Prix. Tragically, his career was cut short due to a pre-season testing accident in 1989 that left him quadriplegic. He later became an advocate for disabled people in motorsport.

name: Piercarlo Ghinzani
paragraph: Piercarlo Ghinzani (born 1952) is a former Italian Formula 1 driver who competed in 76 Grands Prix from 1981 to 1989 for Osella, Toleman, and Ligier. He scored 2 championship points, with a best finish of 5th at the 1984 Dallas Grand Prix. Ghinzani was a journeyman driver known for his persistence with often uncompetitive machinery. He later competed in sports car racing.

name: Pierluigi Martini
paragraph: Pierluigi Martini (born 1961) is a former Italian Formula One driver who competed in 118 Grands Prix from 1985 to 1995. He is best known for driving for the Minardi team, with whom he achieved a career-best finish of 4th place twice, scoring a total of 18 championship points. Martini was renowned for his consistent performances and ability to extract the maximum from uncompetitive cars, often outperforming expectations.

name: Piero Carini
paragraph: Piero Carini (1921 – 1954) was an Italian Formula One driver who competed in 3 World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 and 1953 for Ferrari and Alfa Romeo. He scored no championship points. Carini's F1 career was brief and tragically cut short when he died in a crash during the 1954 Modena Grand Prix, a non-championship event. He was 33 years old at the time of his death.

name: Piero Drogo
paragraph: Piero Drogo (1926 – 1973) was an Italian Formula One driver who competed in a single World Championship Grand Prix, the 1960 Italian Grand Prix, driving a Cooper-Maserati, where he finished 8th. He did not score any championship points. Drogo is more famously known for his work as a car designer and constructor, founding Carrozzeria Sports Cars, which built several Ferrari and other racing car bodies.

name: Piero Dusio
paragraph: Piero Dusio (1899 – 1975) was an Italian racing driver and entrepreneur who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1952 Italian Grand Prix, driving his own Cisitalia D46. He failed to qualify for the race and did not score any points. Dusio was the founder of Cisitalia, a prominent Italian automobile manufacturer, and his involvement in F1 was primarily as an entrant and constructor rather than a dedicated driver.

name: Piero Scotti
paragraph: Piero Scotti (1909 – 1976) was an Italian racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1956 Belgian Grand Prix, driving a Connaught, where he finished 10th. He did not score any championship points. Scotti also competed in other forms of motorsport, including sports car racing, but his F1 career was brief and limited to this single appearance.

name: Piero Taruffi
paragraph: Piero Taruffi (1906 – 1988) was an Italian racing driver who competed in 18 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1950 to 1956. He achieved one Grand Prix victory at the 1952 Swiss Grand Prix and five podium finishes, scoring 41 championship points. Taruffi had a distinguished career that began in motorcycle racing before transitioning to cars, known for his technical prowess and consistency.

name: Pierre Gasly
paragraph: Pierre Gasly (born 1996) is a French Formula One driver who currently drives for Alpine. He made his F1 debut in 2017 and has since driven for Toro Rosso, Red Bull Racing, and AlphaTauri, making 136 Grand Prix starts (as of June 2025). Gasly has achieved several podium finishes, including a memorable maiden win at the 2020 Italian Grand Prix. He is known for his aggressive driving style and ability to extract strong performances from his cars.

name: Pierre-Henri Raphanel
paragraph: Pierre-Henri Raphanel (born 1960) is a French former racing driver who attempted to qualify for 17 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1988 and 1989 for Larrousse, Coloni, and Rial. He made one Grand Prix start at the 1989 Monaco Grand Prix, where he retired, scoring no points. Despite his limited F1 success, he had a successful career in other forms of motorsport, including winning the 1997 24 Hours of Le Mans in the GT1 class.

name: Pierre Levegh
paragraph: Pierre Levegh (1905 – 1955) was a French Formula One driver who competed in 6 Grands Prix between 1950 and 1955, scoring no championship points. He is tragically best known for his involvement in the 1955 Le Mans disaster, where his car crashed and exploded, killing him and 83 spectators. This horrific event led to significant safety improvements in motorsport worldwide. Levegh was a respected privateer driver.

name: Piers Courage
paragraph: Piers Courage (1942 – 1970) was a British Formula One driver who competed in 29 Grands Prix from 1967 to 1970 for BRM, Frank Williams Racing Cars, and De Tomaso. He achieved two podium finishes, scoring 20 championship points. Born into a wealthy brewing family, Courage was known for his bravery and skill on the track. Tragically, he was killed in a crash during the 1970 Dutch Grand Prix at the age of 28.

name: Pietro Fittipaldi
paragraph: Pietro Fittipaldi (born 1996) is a Brazilian-American Formula 1 driver who made 2 Grand Prix starts in the 2020 season with the Haas F1 Team, substituting for the injured Romain Grosjean. He scored no championship points. The grandson of two-time F1 World Champion Emerson Fittipaldi, Pietro has served as a test and reserve driver for Haas since 2019 and continues to compete in various sports car and endurance racing series.

name: Raffaele Marciello
paragraph: Raffaele Marciello (born 1995) is an Italian-Swiss professional racing driver. While he has participated in Formula One test sessions with Sauber and Ferrari, he has never competed in a Formula 1 World Championship Grand Prix. Marciello has had a highly successful career in GT racing, winning the 2022 FIA GT World Challenge Europe and the 2023 24 Hours of Spa. He is known for his speed and consistency behind the wheel.

name: Ralf Schumacher
paragraph: Ralf Schumacher (born 1975) is a retired German Formula 1 driver who competed in 180 Grands Prix from 1997 to 2007. He drove for teams such as Jordan, Williams, and Toyota, achieving six Grand Prix wins and 27 podium finishes, scoring 329 championship points. The younger brother of seven-time F1 World Champion Michael Schumacher, Ralf was known for his aggressive driving style and was a competitive force during his time in F1.

name: Ralph Firman
paragraph: Ralph Firman (born 1975) is a British former racing driver who competed in 15 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix for the Jordan team in 2003. He scored 1 championship point with an 8th-place finish at the 2003 Spanish Grand Prix. Firman's F1 career was relatively short due to injuries, but he later competed successfully in other racing series, including the Japanese Super Formula championship.

name: Raul Boesel
paragraph: Raul Boesel (born 1957) is a Brazilian former Formula One driver who competed in 30 Grands Prix from 1982 to 1983 for March and Ligier. He scored no championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Despite his limited success in F1, Boesel went on to achieve significant success in other series, including IndyCar, where he won the 1987 Michigan 500, and endurance racing, winning the 1991 FIA Sportscar World Championship.

name: Ray Crawford
paragraph: Ray Crawford (1915 – 1996) was an American racing driver who competed in 3 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 (1955, 1956, 1959). He scored no championship points. Crawford had a diverse racing career, competing in various forms of motorsport beyond F1, including sports cars and NASCAR, winning the 1959 Daytona 500 qualifying race.

name: Raymond Sommer
paragraph: Raymond Sommer (1906 – 1950) was a French Formula One driver who competed in 5 Grands Prix during the inaugural 1950 World Championship season. He scored 3 championship points and achieved one 4th place finish. Sommer was a highly successful sports car driver, winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans twice. Tragically, he lost his life in a crash during a sports car event at Cadours, France, in 1950, becoming the first F1 driver to die in a racing accident after the championship's inception.

name: Red Amick
paragraph: Red Amick (1929 – 1995) was an American racing driver who competed in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, both of which were the Indianapolis 500 (1959 and 1960). He scored no championship points. His best finish in these F1-counted races was 8th at the 1960 Indianapolis 500. Amick's career was primarily in Champ Car racing, where he made 32 starts.

name: Reg Parnell
paragraph: Reg Parnell (1911 – 1964) was a British racing driver who competed in 6 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1950 and 1954 for Alfa Romeo, BRM, and Ferrari. He scored 9 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1950 British Grand Prix. Parnell was a highly respected figure in British motorsport, and later became a successful team manager in F1. He passed away at the age of 52.

name: Reine Wisell
paragraph: Reine Wisell (1941 – 2022) was a Swedish racing driver who competed in 23 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1970 and 1974 for Lotus, BRM, and March. He scored 13 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1970 United States Grand Prix. Wisell was known for his calm driving style and also competed in sports car racing.

name: Renato Pirocchi
paragraph: Renato Pirocchi (1933 – 2024) was an Italian Formula 1 driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1961 Italian Grand Prix, driving a Cooper-Maserati, where he failed to qualify. He also competed in several non-championship F1 events. Pirocchi's racing career was relatively short-lived, with no major achievements in the sport's top tier.

name: René Arnoux
paragraph: René Arnoux (born 1948) is a French former Formula One driver who competed in 149 Grands Prix from 1978 to 1989. He achieved seven Grand Prix victories and 22 podium finishes, scoring 181 championship points. Arnoux drove for top teams including Renault and Ferrari and was known for his aggressive driving style, particularly in qualifying. He was a strong contender for the World Championship in the early 1980s.

name: Renzo Zorzi
paragraph: Renzo Zorzi (1946 – 2015) was an Italian Formula 1 driver who competed in 7 Grands Prix between 1975 and 1977 for Frank Williams Racing Cars and Shadow. He scored 1 championship point with a sixth-place finish at the 1977 Brazilian Grand Prix. Zorzi's brief F1 stint is sadly remembered for his indirect involvement in the fatal accident of teammate Tom Pryce at the 1977 South African Grand Prix.

name: Ricardo Londoño
paragraph: Ricardo Londoño (1949 – 2009) was a Colombian racing driver who was entered for one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1981 Brazilian Grand Prix, with Ensign. However, his entry was rejected due to superlicence issues, and he did not participate in the race. Londoño was a relatively experienced driver in Formula Two and Formula Atlantic, but his F1 career was limited to this single, unfulfilled attempt.

name: Ricardo Rodríguez
paragraph: Ricardo Rodríguez (1942 – 1962) was a Mexican Formula 1 driver who competed in 5 Grands Prix from 1961 to 1962 for Ferrari. He made his F1 debut at just 19 years old, becoming the youngest driver to start a Grand Prix at the time. Rodríguez scored one podium finish, a second place at the 1962 Belgian Grand Prix, scoring 4 championship points. Tragically, his life was cut short in a crash during practice for the non-championship 1962 Mexican Grand Prix at the age of 20.

name: Ricardo Rosset
paragraph: Ricardo Rosset (born 1968) is a Brazilian former Formula One driver who competed in 33 Grands Prix in 1996 and 1998 for Footwork and Tyrrell. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 8th. Rosset's time in F1 was marked by inconsistency and a struggle to make a lasting impression on the sport, often facing uncompetitive machinery. He later retired from professional motorsport.

name: Ricardo Zonta
paragraph: Ricardo Zonta (born 1976) is a Brazilian former Formula One driver who competed in 36 Grands Prix from 1999 to 2001 for BAR and Jordan, and later made sporadic appearances as a test driver. He scored 3 championship points, with a best finish of 6th. Zonta was known for his speed, particularly in sports car racing where he won the 1998 FIA GT Championship and the 2000 Le Mans 24 Hours in class. His F1 career was hampered by uncompetitive machinery and injuries.

name: Ricardo Zunino
paragraph: Ricardo Zunino (born 1949) is a retired Argentine Formula One driver who competed in 10 Grands Prix in 1979, 1980, and 1981 for Brabham and Tyrrell. He scored no championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Zunino is perhaps best known for replacing the injured Niki Lauda at Brabham during the 1979 Canadian Grand Prix without prior F1 experience. His F1 career was relatively short-lived.

name: Riccardo Paletti
paragraph: Riccardo Paletti (1958 – 1982) was an Italian Formula 1 driver who tragically lost his life in a crash during the 1982 Canadian Grand Prix. He made 2 Grand Prix starts. Paletti began his racing career in Italy and made his F1 debut with the Osella team at just 24 years old. His fatal accident occurred when he collided with Didier Pironi's stalled Ferrari on the starting grid. His death was a somber moment for the F1 community.

name: Riccardo Patrese
paragraph: Riccardo Patrese (born 1954) is a retired Italian Formula 1 driver who competed in a record 256 Grands Prix from 1977 to 1993, a record he held for over a decade. He achieved six Grand Prix victories and 37 podium finishes, scoring 281 championship points. Patrese drove for several teams, including Arrows, Brabham, Williams, and Benetton, and was known for his longevity, consistency, and a memorable rivalry with Ayrton Senna.

name: Richard Attwood
paragraph: Richard Attwood (born 1940) is a British former racing driver who competed in 17 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1964 to 1969 for BRM, Lotus, and Cooper. He scored 11 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a second place at the 1968 Monaco Grand Prix. Attwood is also highly successful in endurance racing, winning the 1970 24 Hours of Le Mans for Porsche. He was known for his versatility as a driver.

name: Richard Robarts
paragraph: Richard Robarts (born 1944) is a British former Formula 1 driver who competed in 3 Grands Prix in the 1974 season for the Brabham and Iso Marlboro teams. He failed to score any championship points. Robarts' F1 career was relatively short-lived due to sponsorship issues, but he did show promise in junior formulae before his brief foray into the top tier of motorsport.

name: Richie Ginther
paragraph: Richie Ginther (1930 – 1989) was an American Formula One driver who competed in 52 Grands Prix from 1960 to 1967 for Ferrari, BRM, and Honda. He scored 102 championship points, achieved 14 top-6 finishes, and four podiums, including a memorable victory at the 1965 Mexican Grand Prix, which was Honda's first F1 win. Ginther was known for his smooth driving style and technical feedback, helping to develop Honda's F1 program.

name: Rikky von Opel
paragraph: Rikky von Opel (born 1947) is a former Formula One driver from Liechtenstein who competed in 14 Grands Prix in 1973 and 1974 for Ensign and Brabham. He scored no championship points. Von Opel was a member of the wealthy and influential Opel family. His F1 career was brief and he quickly withdrew from the sport after struggling to find competitive drives, largely due to lack of funding from the family.

name: Rio Haryanto
paragraph: Rio Haryanto (born 1993) is an Indonesian former Formula One driver who made 12 Grand Prix starts in the 2016 season with the Manor Racing team. He was the first Indonesian driver to compete in the championship, but failed to score any championship points. Haryanto's F1 career was limited by the competitiveness of his team and sponsorship issues, leading to his replacement mid-season by Esteban Ocon. He later competed in endurance racing.

name: Rob Schroeder
paragraph: Rob Schroeder (1926 – 2004) was an American Formula One driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1962 United States Grand Prix, in a Lotus-Climax. He finished 10th in that race and did not score any championship points. Schroeder's F1 career was limited to this single appearance, and he was more active in sports car racing in the United States.

name: Robert Doornbos
paragraph: Robert Doornbos (born 1981) is a Dutch former Formula One driver who competed in 11 Grands Prix from 2005 to 2006 for Minardi and Red Bull Racing. He scored no championship points. Doornbos was known for his speed in junior formulae and later achieved success in other open-wheel series, including winning races in Champ Car and A1 Grand Prix. He also served as a test and reserve driver in F1.

name: Robert Kubica
paragraph: Robert Kubica (born 1984) is a Polish Formula 1 driver who competed in 97 Grands Prix from 2006 to 2010 and again in 2019 and 2021 as a reserve driver. He achieved 12 podium finishes and a maiden Grand Prix victory at the 2008 Canadian Grand Prix, scoring 276 championship points. Kubica's F1 career was marked by his speed and consistency, earning him a reputation as one of the sport's top drivers before a serious rally crash in 2011 severely affected his arm.

name: Robert La Caze
paragraph: Robert La Caze (1917 – 1999) was a French-Moroccan racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1958 Moroccan Grand Prix, in a Cooper, where he finished 14th. He did not score any championship points. La Caze was a pioneer for Moroccan motorsport, being the first driver from Morocco to compete in Formula One. His F1 career was modest, but he had success in local sports car events.

name: Robert Manzon
paragraph: Robert Manzon (1917 – 2015) was a French Formula 1 driver who competed in 28 Grands Prix from 1950 to 1956 for Gordini and Ferrari. He achieved two podium finishes, scoring 16 championship points. Manzon was a consistent and reliable driver in the early years of F1, often demonstrating strong performances despite driving for smaller teams. He was the last surviving driver from the inaugural 1950 F1 World Championship.

name: Robert O'Brien
paragraph: Robert O'Brien (1906 – 1993) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1953 Indianapolis 500. He retired from the race and did not score any championship points. O'Brien's F1 involvement was limited to this single event during the period when the Indy 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship. He was primarily active in American Championship Car racing.

name: Robert Shwartzman
paragraph: Robert Shwartzman (born 1999) is a Russian-Israeli Formula 1 test and reserve driver for the Ferrari team. While he has participated in several F1 free practice sessions, he has not yet made a Grand Prix start. Shwartzman has shown impressive skills in junior formulae, winning the 2019 FIA Formula 3 Championship and finishing runner-up in the 2020 Formula 2 Championship. He is highly regarded as a potential future full-time F1 driver.

name: Robert Wickens
paragraph: Robert Wickens (born 1989) is a Canadian former racing driver who was a test and reserve driver for the Marussia Virgin Racing Formula One team in 2011, but never made a Grand Prix start. He had a highly successful career in junior open-wheel formulae and DTM, winning the 2009 Formula Renault 3.5 Series. A serious crash in IndyCar in 2018 left him with spinal cord injuries, ending his professional open-wheel racing career. He now competes in sports car racing with hand controls.

name: Roberto Bonomi
paragraph: Roberto Bonomi (1919 – 1992) was an Argentine Formula One driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1960 Argentine Grand Prix, driving a Cooper-Maserati, where he finished 11th. He did not score any championship points. Bonomi's F1 career was relatively short-lived, with his main focus on sports car racing and touring car racing in Argentina.

name: Roberto Bussinello
paragraph: Roberto Bussinello (1927 – 1999) was an Italian Formula One driver who competed in 3 Grands Prix in 1961 and 1965 for De Tomaso and BRM. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 11th. Bussinello's F1 career was brief and not particularly successful, overshadowed by his involvement in sports car racing and his role as a test driver for Alfa Romeo.

name: Roberto Guerrero
paragraph: Roberto Guerrero (born 1958) is a Colombian former Formula One driver who competed in 29 Grands Prix from 1982 to 1983 for Ensign and Theodore. He failed to score any championship points. Despite limited success in F1, "Robby" went on to have a highly successful career in IndyCar, winning two races and achieving multiple podium finishes, including a memorable second place at the 1987 Indianapolis 500.

name: Roberto Lippi
paragraph: Roberto Lippi (1926 – 2011) was an Italian Formula One driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1961 Italian Grand Prix, driving a De Tomaso. He failed to qualify for the race and did not score any points. Lippi's F1 career was very brief, limited to this single attempt, and he was primarily active in national-level racing in Italy.

name: Roberto Merhi
paragraph: Roberto Merhi (born 1991) is a Spanish Formula 1 driver who made 13 Grand Prix starts in the 2015 season with the Manor Marussia F1 Team. He scored no championship points. Although his F1 career was relatively short and with an uncompetitive team, Merhi has had success in other series, including winning the 2011 Formula 3 Euro Series. He continues to compete in various forms of motorsport, including endurance racing.

name: Roberto Mieres
paragraph: Roberto Mieres (1924 – 2020) was an Argentine racing driver who competed in 17 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1954 to 1955 for Maserati. He scored 13 championship points and achieved a best finish of 4th place three times. Mieres was known for his versatility, competing successfully in various forms of motorsport beyond Formula One, including sports cars and offshore powerboat racing.

name: Roberto Moreno
paragraph: Roberto Moreno (born 1959) is a Brazilian former Formula 1 driver who competed in 42 Grands Prix from 1989 to 1995 for teams like Coloni, EuroBrun, Benetton, and Andrea Moda. He achieved one podium finish, a second place at the 1990 Japanese Grand Prix, scoring 15 championship points. Known for his versatility and persistence, "Tinguinha" also had a highly successful career in CART and IndyCar, winning two races.

name: Robin Frijns
paragraph: Robin Frijns (born 1991) is a Dutch racing driver who served as a test and reserve driver for the Sauber and Caterham Formula 1 teams, but has not made a Grand Prix start. He is highly successful in other categories, including winning the 2012 Formula Renault 3.5 Series and the 2020-21 Formula E World Championship. Frijns is known for his aggressive driving style and adaptability to various racing cars, excelling in endurance racing and DTM.

name: Robin Montgomerie-Charrington
paragraph: Robin Montgomerie-Charrington (1915 – 2007) was a British racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1952 Belgian Grand Prix, driving an Aston Butterworth. He finished 14th in the race and did not score any championship points. His F1 career was limited to this single appearance, but he was active in club racing and sports car events.

name: Robin Widdows
paragraph: Robin Widdows (born 1942) is a British former racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1968 British Grand Prix, in a Cooper, where he retired. He failed to score any championship points. Widdows also competed in other racing series, including Formula 2, sports car racing, and was a successful bobsledder, representing Great Britain at the Winter Olympics.

name: Rodger Ward
paragraph: Rodger Ward (1921 – 2004) was an American racing driver who competed in 12 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 from 1951 to 1963. He was a two-time Indy 500 winner, taking victories in 1959 and 1962, scoring a total of 15 championship points in F1. Ward is considered one of the greatest drivers in Indy history, known for his consistent and clean driving style.

name: Rodney Nuckey
paragraph: Rodney Nuckey (1929 – 2000) was a British Formula One driver who participated in 2 World Championship Grands Prix in 1953 (British and German Grands Prix), driving a Cooper. He failed to score any championship points. Nuckey's F1 career was relatively short-lived, with limited entries, but he competed in various non-championship Formula One events and other national racing series.

name: Rodolfo González
paragraph: Rodolfo González (born 1986) is a Venezuelan former Formula One test driver who participated in several free practice sessions for Marussia in 2013 and 2014, but never made a Grand Prix start. He also competed in various junior formulae, including GP2 Series, where he achieved a podium finish. González has since continued to be involved in motorsports, competing in endurance racing.

name: Roelof Wunderink
paragraph: Roelof Wunderink (born 1948) is a Dutch former racing driver who competed in 6 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in the 1975 season for the Ensign team. He failed to score any championship points. Wunderink's F1 career was brief and marred by uncompetitive machinery and a serious accident at the Austrian Grand Prix. He later retired from professional racing due to his injuries.

name: Roger Laurent
paragraph: Roger Laurent (1913 – 1997) was a Belgian racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 (Belgian and German Grands Prix) for HWM and Ferrari. He scored no championship points. Laurent's F1 career was limited to these two appearances, and he was primarily active in sports car racing.

name: Roger Loyer
paragraph: Roger Loyer (1907 – 1988) was a French racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1954 Argentine Grand Prix, in a Gordini, finishing 8th. He scored no championship points. Loyer was primarily a successful motorcycle racer, competing in the Grand Prix motorcycle racing world championships before his brief foray into Formula 1.

name: Roger Penske
paragraph: Roger Penske (born 1937) is an American former racing driver and highly successful businessman, best known as the founder and owner of Team Penske, a dominant professional racing team in IndyCar and NASCAR. He made 2 Formula One World Championship starts in 1961 and 1962, scoring no points. Penske is a global motorsport icon, but his influence is primarily as a team owner and entrepreneur rather than an F1 driver.

name: Roger Williamson
paragraph: Roger Williamson (1948 – 1973) was a British Formula One driver who tragically lost his life during his second Grand Prix start at the 1973 Dutch Grand Prix. He was 25 years old when his car crashed and caught fire, and he was unable to be rescued. Williamson was a rising star in F1, having shown immense promise in junior formulae. His death led to significant changes in F1 safety procedures.

name: Roland Ratzenberger
paragraph: Roland Ratzenberger (1960 – 1994) was an Austrian Formula 1 driver who tragically lost his life during the qualifying session for the 1994 San Marino Grand Prix. He had made his F1 debut earlier that year, making 3 Grand Prix starts. Ratzenberger's fatal crash occurred just a day before the death of Ayrton Senna, marking a dark weekend in F1 history and prompting significant safety reforms in the sport.

name: Rolf Stommelen
paragraph: Rolf Stommelen (1943 – 1983) was a German Formula 1 driver who competed in 53 Grands Prix from 1969 to 1976 for teams like Brabham, Surtees, and Lola. He scored 14 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1970 Austrian Grand Prix. Stommelen was known for his versatility, competing successfully in sports cars and endurance racing. Tragically, his life was cut short in a crash during a sports car race in 1983.

name: Romain Grosjean
paragraph: Romain Grosjean (born 1986) is a French-Swiss former Formula 1 driver who competed in 179 Grands Prix from 2009 to 2020 for Renault, Lotus, and Haas. He achieved 10 podium finishes, scoring 391 championship points. Grosjean was known for his aggressive driving style and ability to extract performance from his cars, though he was also involved in several high-profile incidents. His F1 career ended after a dramatic and fiery crash at the 2020 Bahrain Grand Prix, from which he made a miraculous escape.

name: Ron Flockhart
paragraph: Ron Flockhart (1923 – 1962) was a British racing driver who competed in 13 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1956 and 1960 for BRM and Cooper. He scored 6 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1956 Italian Grand Prix. Flockhart also had success in endurance racing, winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans twice. He tragically died in an airplane crash in 1962.

name: Ronnie Bucknum
paragraph: Ronnie Bucknum (1936 – 1992) was an American Formula One driver who competed in 11 Grands Prix from 1964 to 1966 for Honda. He scored 2 championship points, with a best finish of 5th at the 1965 Mexican Grand Prix. Bucknum was one of the first drivers to compete for Honda in Formula 1 and was known for his experience in sports car racing. He later competed in IndyCar and NASCAR.

name: Ronnie Peterson
paragraph: Ronnie Peterson (1944 – 1978) was a Swedish Formula 1 driver known for his impressive car control and 'SuperSwede' nickname. He competed in 123 Grands Prix from 1970 to 1978 for March, Lotus, and Tyrrell, achieving 10 Grand Prix victories and 26 podium finishes, scoring 206 championship points. Tragically, Peterson's life was cut short due to complications from injuries sustained in a crash at the 1978 Italian Grand Prix, a day after the event.

name: Roy Nissany
paragraph: Roy Nissany (born 1994) is an Israeli-French racing driver who has served as a test and reserve driver for Williams and Alpine Formula 1 teams since 2020. While he has participated in several F1 free practice sessions, he has not made a Grand Prix start. Nissany has competed in various junior formulae, including Formula 2, and continues to work towards his Formula 1 dream through testing and development roles.

name: Roy Salvadori
paragraph: Roy Salvadori (1922 – 2012) was a British racing driver who competed in 47 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1952 to 1962 for teams like Connaught, Maserati, and Cooper. He scored 19 championship points and achieved two podium finishes. Salvadori is perhaps best known for his endurance racing exploits, winning the 1959 24 Hours of Le Mans alongside Carroll Shelby.

name: Rubens Barrichello
paragraph: Rubens Barrichello (born 1972) is a Brazilian former Formula One driver who competed in 322 Grands Prix from 1993 to 2011, holding the record for most F1 starts until 2020. He achieved 11 Grand Prix victories and 68 podium finishes, scoring 658 championship points. Barrichello was a consistent top-level competitor, notably serving as Michael Schumacher's teammate at Ferrari during their dominant era. He later competed in IndyCar and Stock Car Brazil.

name: Rudi Fischer
paragraph: Rudi Fischer (1912 – 1976) was a Swiss Formula One driver who competed in 8 World Championship Grands Prix between 1951 and 1952 for Ferrari. He scored 10 championship points and achieved two podium finishes, both third places at the 1952 Swiss Grand Prix and 1952 German Grand Prix. Fischer was a prominent privateer in the early 1950s F1 season, competing with his own Écurie Espadon team.

name: Rudolf Krause
paragraph: Rudolf Krause (1907 – 1987) was a German Formula One driver who competed in 2 World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 and 1953, driving a BMW. He failed to score any championship points. Krause also participated in several non-championship F1 events. His F1 career was brief and primarily focused on national German racing in the early 1950s.

name: Rudolf Schoeller
paragraph: Rudolf Schoeller (1902 – 1978) was a Swiss Formula One driver who participated in one World Championship Grand Prix, the 1952 German Grand Prix, driving a Ferrari for the Écurie Espadon team. He retired from the race and did not score any points. Schoeller's brief foray into F1 remains a footnote in the history of the sport.

name: Rupert Keegan
paragraph: Rupert Keegan (1955 – 2024) is a British former racing driver who competed in 25 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1977 and 1982 for teams like Hesketh, Surtees, and March. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Despite limited success, Keegan was known for his perseverance and entrepreneurial spirit in the competitive world of F1.

name: Ryan Briscoe
paragraph: Ryan Briscoe (born 1981) is an Australian professional racing driver. While he had a test driver role with Toyota's Formula 1 team in 2004, he never made a Grand Prix start. Briscoe is highly successful in IndyCar, winning eight races, and in endurance racing, including winning the 2012 24 Hours of Daytona. He has also competed in the FIA World Endurance Championship.

name: Ryō Hirakawa
paragraph: Ryō Hirakawa (born 1994) is a Japanese professional racing driver who is currently a test and reserve driver for the McLaren Formula 1 team, having previously held similar roles with Alpine. While he has participated in F1 test sessions, he has not made a Grand Prix start. Hirakawa is a highly successful endurance racer, winning the 2022 and 2023 24 Hours of Le Mans and the 2022 FIA World Endurance Championship for Toyota Gazoo Racing.

name: Sakon Yamamoto
paragraph: Sakon Yamamoto (born 1982) is a Japanese former Formula 1 driver who competed in 21 Grands Prix between 2006 and 2010 for Super Aguri, Spyker, and HRT. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 12th. Despite his relatively short F1 career, Yamamoto gained experience and competed in other series such as GP2 and the World Endurance Championship. He later served as a goodwill ambassador for the Japanese Olympic Committee.

name: Sam Hanks
paragraph: Sam Hanks (1914 – 1994) was an American racing driver who competed in 13 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1950 and 1957. He won the 1957 Indianapolis 500, scoring 8 championship points. Hanks was known for his consistent driving style and achieved three top-five finishes in the Indy 500 during his F1-counted career. He retired from racing immediately after his victory.

name: Sam Posey
paragraph: Sam Posey (born 1944) is a former American racing driver who competed in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix (1971 and 1972 US Grands Prix), both in a Brabham, where he retired from both races and scored no points. Posey is more notable for his success in other forms of motorsport, such as the Can-Am series and IMSA GT Championship, and later became a respected television commentator for motorsport.

name: Sam Tingle
paragraph: Sam Tingle (1921 – 2208) is a British former racing driver who competed in 5 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix (all South African Grands Prix) between 1963 and 1969. He failed to score any championship points. Tingle also competed in various non-championship F1 events and was a regular competitor in the South African national championships. He passed away on December 12, 2008.

name: Satoru Nakajima
paragraph: Satoru Nakajima (born 1953) is a Japanese former Formula One driver who competed in 80 Grands Prix from 1987 to 1991 for Lotus and Tyrrell. He scored 16 championship points, with a best finish of 4th. Nakajima was the first full-time Japanese Formula 1 driver and was often remembered for his impressive qualifying performances, particularly during his time with Lotus. He later founded his own successful Formula Nippon team.

name: Satoshi Motoyama
paragraph: Satoshi Motoyama (born 1971) is a Japanese former racing driver who participated in one Formula One free practice session for Jordan at the 2003 Japanese Grand Prix, but never made a Grand Prix start. He is a highly successful driver in Japanese motorsport, being a four-time Formula Nippon champion (1998, 2001, 2003, 2005) and a multiple Super GT champion. He was known for his skills and consistency on the track.

name: Scott Speed
paragraph: Scott Speed (born 1983) is a former American Formula One driver who competed in 28 Grands Prix from 2006 to 2007 for the Toro Rosso team. He failed to score any championship points. Speed's time in F1 was marked by some on-track incidents and a challenging relationship with the team. He later achieved significant success in various forms of American motorsport, including NASCAR and rallycross, winning multiple championships.

name: Sean Gelael
paragraph: Sean Gelael (born 1996) is an Indonesian racing driver who has served as a test and development driver for the Toro Rosso and AlphaTauri Formula 1 teams since 2017. While he has participated in several F1 free practice sessions, he has not yet made a Grand Prix start. Gelael has competed in various junior formulae, including Formula 2, and is currently active in the FIA World Endurance Championship, where he has achieved wins.

name: Sebastian Vettel
paragraph: Sebastian Vettel (born 1987) is a highly accomplished German former Formula 1 driver who won four consecutive World Drivers' Championship titles from 2010 to 2013 with Red Bull Racing. He made 299 Grand Prix starts, achieving 53 victories and 122 podium finishes. Known for his exceptional qualifying skills, aggressive driving style, and meticulous preparation, Vettel is considered one of the greatest drivers in F1 history. He retired from F1 at the end of the 2022 season.

name: Sébastien Bourdais
paragraph: Sébastien Bourdais (born 1979) is a French professional racing driver who competed in 27 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 2008 and 2009 for the Toro Rosso team. He scored 6 championship points. Bourdais is highly successful in other top-tier racing series, having won four consecutive Champ Car World Series titles from 2004 to 2007. He continues to compete in endurance racing and IMSA.

name: Sébastien Buemi
paragraph: Sébastien Buemi (born 1988) is a Swiss professional racing driver who competed in 55 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 2009 to 2011 for the Toro Rosso team. He scored 29 championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Buemi has achieved significant success in other racing series, winning the FIA World Endurance Championship four times and the 24 Hours of Le Mans four times, as well as the Formula E Championship.

name: Sergey Sirotkin
paragraph: Sergey Sirotkin (born 1995) is a Russian former Formula One driver who competed in 21 Grands Prix in the 2018 season with the Williams team. He scored 1 championship point with a 10th-place finish at the 2018 Italian Grand Prix. Sirotkin's Formula One career was relatively short-lived as he was replaced for the 2019 season. He previously competed in GP2 and Formula Renault 3.5.

name: Sergio Mantovani
paragraph: Sergio Mantovani (1929 – 2001) was an Italian Formula One driver who competed in 8 World Championship Grands Prix from 1953 to 1955 for Maserati. He scored 4 championship points and achieved a best finish of 4th place twice. Mantovani's F1 career was brief and he later became involved in the automotive industry. He was a respected privateer in the early 1950s F1 era.

name: Sergio Pérez
paragraph: Sergio Pérez (born 1990) is a Mexican Formula 1 driver currently racing for Red Bull Racing. He has competed in 282 Grands Prix (as of June 2025), securing 6 Grand Prix victories and 39 podium finishes. Known for his consistent performances and tire management, "Checo" has established himself as a top-tier driver in the sport, playing a crucial supporting role for his team and challenging for race wins.

name: Shinji Nakano
paragraph: Shinji Nakano (born 1971) is a retired Japanese Formula One driver who competed in 33 Grands Prix from 1997 to 1998 for Prost and Minardi. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th. After F1, Nakano went on to compete successfully in other series, including the Indy Racing League and the Japanese Super GT series. He was known for his speed and consistency in other categories.

name: Shorty Templeman
paragraph: Shorty Templeman (1919 – 1962) was an American racing driver who competed in 5 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1955 and 1962. He scored 4 championship points, with a best finish of 4th at the 1961 Indianapolis 500. Templeman was primarily an IndyCar driver, known for his versatility and speed. Tragically, his life was cut short in a sprint car crash in 1962.

name: Siegfried Stohr
paragraph: Siegfried Stohr (born 1952) is a former Italian Formula One driver who competed in 9 Grands Prix in the 1981 season for the Arrows team. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Stohr's F1 career was brief and is perhaps most notable for his involvement in a first-lap incident at the 1981 Belgian Grand Prix. After retiring from racing, he became a psychologist and driving safety expert.

name: Silvio Moser
paragraph: Silvio Moser (1941 – 1974) was a Swiss Formula One driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix between 1967 and 1971. He scored 3 championship points, with a best finish of 5th at the 1969 United States Grand Prix. Moser primarily competed with his own privateer Brabham and Bellasi cars. His promising career was sadly cut short by a serious racing accident in 1974 from which he later succumbed to his injuries.

name: Skip Barber
paragraph: Skip Barber (born 1936) is a former American racing driver who made 5 Formula One World Championship starts in 1971 and 1972 for March, scoring no points. He is more famously known for founding the Skip Barber Racing School, a prestigious racing institution that has trained numerous successful drivers. Barber was a highly accomplished driver in various open-wheel series before and after his brief F1 stint.

name: Slim Borgudd
paragraph: Slim Borgudd (1946 – 2023) was a Swedish Formula 1 driver who competed in 10 Grands Prix in 1981 and 1982 for ATS and Tyrrell. He scored 1 championship point with a 6th place at the 1981 British Grand Prix. Before his F1 career, Borgudd was a successful professional drummer, notably playing for ABBA's backing band. His unique background made him a memorable figure in the F1 paddock.

name: Spider Webb
paragraph: Spider Webb (1910 – 1990) was an American racing driver who competed in 3 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 (1950, 1953, 1954). He scored no championship points. Webb was primarily an IndyCar driver, and his F1 involvement was limited to these races during the period when the Indianapolis 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship.

name: Stefan Bellof
paragraph: Stefan Bellof (1957 – 1985) was a promising German Formula 1 driver who competed in 20 Grands Prix in 1984 and 1985 for Tyrrell. He scored 4 championship points, with a best finish of 3rd at the 1984 Monaco Grand Prix. Bellof showed immense speed and potential, particularly in sports car racing where he won the 1984 World Endurance Championship. Tragically, his life was cut short in a crash during a sportscar race at Spa-Francorchamps in 1985 at just 27 years old.

name: Stefan Johansson
paragraph: Stefan Johansson (born 1956) is a Swedish former Formula 1 driver who competed in 103 Grands Prix from 1980 to 1991 for teams including Tyrrell, Ferrari, and McLaren. He achieved 12 podium finishes, scoring 88 championship points. Nicknamed "The Moose," Johansson was known for his consistent performances and points-scoring ability, often outperforming his machinery. He later had a successful career in sports car racing, winning the 1997 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Stefano Modena
paragraph: Stefano Modena (born 1963) is a former Italian Formula 1 driver who competed in 73 Grands Prix from 1987 to 1992 for teams like Brabham, Tyrrell, and Jordan. He scored 17 championship points and achieved two podium finishes. Modena was remembered for his impressive qualifying performances and his ability to extract the maximum from his machinery, particularly during his time with Tyrrell. He later found success in touring car racing.

name: Stéphane Sarrazin
paragraph: Stéphane Sarrazin (born 1975) is a French racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1999 Brazilian Grand Prix, for the Minardi team, but retired. He also served as a test driver for Prost and Toyota. Sarrazin is highly accomplished in other forms of motorsport, particularly in sports car racing, where he has multiple wins and podiums in the FIA World Endurance Championship and the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Stephen South
paragraph: Stephen South (born 1952) is a British former racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1980 United States Grand Prix West, for the McLaren team, but failed to qualify. Although he never made a Grand Prix start, he had a notable career in other formulae, including winning the 1979 British Formula 3 Championship. South's promising career was tragically cut short due to a serious injury sustained in a racing accident in 1980.

name: Stirling Moss
paragraph: Stirling Moss (1929 – 2020) was a renowned British Formula One driver, widely regarded as one of the greatest never to win a World Championship. He competed in 66 Grands Prix from 1951 to 1961, achieving 16 victories and 24 podium finishes, scoring 186.5 championship points. Moss was known for his exceptional skill, versatility, and sportsmanship. His impressive career across various racing disciplines cemented his legacy as a global motorsport icon.

name: Stoffel Vandoorne
paragraph: Stoffel Vandoorne (born 1992) is a Belgian racing driver who competed in 41 Formula 1 Grands Prix in 2016, 2017, and 2018 for McLaren. He scored 13 championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Vandoorne has since achieved significant success in other racing series, winning the 2021-22 Formula E World Championship and the 2022 FIA World Endurance Championship. He currently serves as a test and reserve driver for Aston Martin in F1.

name: Stuart Lewis-Evans
paragraph: Stuart Lewis-Evans (1930 – 1958) was a British Formula One driver who competed in 14 Grands Prix in 1957 and 1958 for Vanwall. He scored 16 championship points and achieved two podium finishes. Lewis-Evans had a promising career, but it was tragically cut short when he suffered severe burns in a crash at the 1958 Moroccan Grand Prix. He sadly passed away six days later due to complications from his injuries.

name: Susie Wolff
paragraph: Susie Wolff (born 1982) is a British former racing driver and current Managing Director of the F1 Academy. She participated in four Formula One free practice sessions for Williams in 2014 and 2015, becoming the first woman to take part in an F1 Grand Prix weekend in 22 years. Wolff is a vocal advocate for women in motorsport and has been instrumental in promoting diversity and inclusion within the sport. She is married to Mercedes F1 Team Principal Toto Wolff.

name: Taki Inoue
paragraph: Taki Inoue (born 1963) is a former Japanese Formula One driver who competed in 18 Grands Prix in 1994 and 1995 for Simtek and Footwork. He failed to score any championship points. Inoue is perhaps best known for being involved in two unusual incidents during Grand Prix weekends, including being hit by a course car. Despite his limited success, Inoue remains a popular and humorous figure among F1 fans due to his self-deprecating wit.

name: Takuma Sato
paragraph: Takuma Sato (born 1977) is a Japanese former Formula 1 driver who competed in 90 Grands Prix from 2002 to 2008 for Jordan, BAR, and Super Aguri. He scored 44 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 2004 United States Grand Prix. Sato is known for his aggressive driving style and never-give-up attitude, which made him a fan favorite. He later found significant success in IndyCar, winning the Indianapolis 500 twice (2017 and 2020).

name: Tarso Marques
paragraph: Tarso Marques (born 1976) is a Brazilian former racing driver who competed in 24 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1996 and 2001 for the Minardi team. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 8th. Marques' F1 career was marked by limited success with uncompetitive machinery. He later competed in Champ Car and other touring car series in Brazil.

name: Ted Whiteaway
paragraph: Ted Whiteaway (1928 – 1995) was a British Formula One driver who competed in one Grand Prix, the 1955 British Grand Prix, driving a HWM-Alta. He finished 15th and failed to score any championship points. His Grand Prix career was brief and largely hampered by a lack of competitive machinery. Whiteaway was primarily active in national-level racing.

name: Teddy Pilette
paragraph: Teddy Pilette (born 1942) is a Belgian former racing driver who participated in 4 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1974 to 1978 for Brabham and BRM. He failed to qualify for most of his entries and did not score any championship points. Pilette was a successful driver in other formulae, notably winning the 1971 European Formula 5000 Championship. His F1 career was brief and relatively unsuccessful.

name: Teo Fabi
paragraph: Teo Fabi (born 1955) is a former Italian Formula One driver who competed in 43 Grands Prix from 1984 to 1987 for Toleman, Spirit, and Benetton. He achieved two pole positions and two third-place finishes, scoring 23 championship points. Fabi was known for his speed and talent, often outperforming his machinery. His younger brother, Corrado Fabi, also competed in F1, and they are the only siblings to have both achieved pole positions in F1.

name: Theo Fitzau
paragraph: Theo Fitzau (1923 – 1982) was a German Formula One driver who competed in one Grand Prix, the 1953 German Grand Prix, driving for the EMW team. He retired from the race due to mechanical failure and failed to score any championship points. Fitzau's F1 career was very short-lived, limited to this single appearance, and he was primarily active in sports car racing.

name: Theo Helfrich
paragraph: Theo Helfrich (1913 – 1978) was a German Formula One driver who competed in 3 Grands Prix between 1952 and 1954 for Veritas and Klenk. He scored no championship points, with a best finish of 12th. Helfrich also participated in several non-championship events and was a veteran of German motorsport before and during the early years of the F1 World Championship.

name: Théo Pourchaire
paragraph: Théo Pourchaire (born 2003) is a French professional racing driver and a current test and reserve driver for the Stake F1 Team Kick Sauber. While he has participated in F1 test sessions, he has not made a Grand Prix start. Pourchaire is a highly accomplished junior driver, having won the 2020 FIA Formula 3 Championship and the 2023 FIA Formula 2 Championship. He is considered one of the most promising young talents for a future F1 race seat.

name: Thierry Boutsen
paragraph: Thierry Boutsen (born 1957) is a Belgian former Formula One driver who competed in 163 Grands Prix from 1983 to 1993 for teams like Arrows, Benetton, and Williams. He achieved three Grand Prix victories and 15 podium finishes, scoring 132 championship points. Boutsen was known for his consistent and reliable performances, often scoring points and helping his teams secure valuable constructor's championship points.

name: Tiago Monteiro
paragraph: Tiago Monteiro (born 1976) is a Portuguese former Formula One driver who competed in 37 Grands Prix from 2005 to 2006 for Jordan and Midland F1 (later Spyker MF1). He scored 7 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the chaotic 2005 United States Grand Prix. After F1, Monteiro became highly successful in touring car racing, winning races and competing for the World Touring Car Championship title.

name: Tiff Needell
paragraph: Tiff Needell (born 1951) is a British former racing driver who competed in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1980 for the Ensign team. He failed to score any championship points. Needell later found significant success as a television presenter, best known for co-hosting the popular motoring shows "Top Gear" and "Fifth Gear." He also continued to compete in endurance racing, including the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Tim Parnell
paragraph: Tim Parnell (1932 – 2017) was a British former racing driver who participated in 4 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1959 and 1961 for Cooper and Lotus. He failed to score any championship points. The son of Reg Parnell, Tim later became a team manager in F1 for BRM and Parnell Racing. His driving career was brief, but he remained a notable figure in the F1 paddock through his management roles.

name: Tim Schenken
