paragraph: Tim Schenken (born 1943) is a retired Australian Formula One driver who competed in 34 Grands Prix between 1970 and 1974 for De Tomaso, Brabham, Surtees, and Williams. He scored 7 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1971 Austrian Grand Prix. After F1, Schenken founded Tiga Race Cars and became a prominent figure in motorsport administration, including race director for Australian events.

name: Timmy Mayer
paragraph: Timmy Mayer (1938 – 1964) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1962 United States Grand Prix, in a Cooper, finishing 9th. He did not score any championship points. Mayer was a promising young talent and the younger brother of Teddy Mayer, who later became McLaren's team principal. Tragically, his life was cut short in a racing accident at Longford Circuit in Tasmania in 1964.

name: Timo Glock
paragraph: Timo Glock (born 1982) is a retired German Formula One driver who competed in 91 Grands Prix from 2004 to 2012 for Jordan, Toyota, Virgin, and Marussia. He achieved three podium finishes, scoring 51 championship points. Glock was known for his consistent performances and was a key figure in the development of the Toyota F1 car. He later found success in DTM, winning races and challenging for the championship.

name: Tom Belsø
paragraph: Tom Belsø (1942 – 2020) was a Danish Formula One driver who made one Grand Prix start, at the 1974 Swedish Grand Prix, for the Frank Williams Racing Cars team, where he retired due to clutch issues. He attempted to qualify for five races in total. Belsø failed to score any championship points and his F1 career was relatively short-lived due to a lack of consistent sponsorship.

name: Tom Bridger
paragraph: Tom Bridger (1934 – 1991) was a British racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1958 Moroccan Grand Prix, in a Cooper. He retired from the race and did not score any championship points. Bridger's F1 career was brief and limited to this single appearance, as he was primarily active in sports car and Formula Junior racing.

name: Tom Jones
paragraph: Tom Jones (1923 – 1993) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1950 Indianapolis 500. He retired from the race and did not score any championship points. His F1 involvement was limited to this single event during the period when the Indianapolis 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship.

name: Tom Pryce
paragraph: Tom Pryce (1949 – 1977) was a British Formula 1 driver who competed in 42 Grands Prix from 1974 to 1977 for Token and Shadow. He scored 8 championship points and achieved one podium finish in a non-championship race. Pryce showed immense talent and potential during his short career. Tragically, his life was cut short in a fatal accident during the 1977 South African Grand Prix, a devastating loss to the F1 community.

name: Tomáš Enge
paragraph: Tomáš Enge (born 1976) is a Czech former racing driver who made 3 Formula One World Championship starts in 2001 for the Prost team, scoring no points. He was the first Czech driver to compete in F1. While his F1 career was brief, Enge had a successful career in other formulae, including winning the 2002 Formula 3000 Championship, though he was later stripped of the title due to a failed drug test. He also competed successfully in sports car racing.

name: Tommy Byrne
paragraph: Tommy Byrne (born 1958) is a former Irish racing driver who competed in 5 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1982 for Theodore. He failed to qualify for 3 of his entries and did not score any championship points. Byrne's brief F1 stint was marked by a lack of competitive machinery. He was known for his raw speed in junior formulae, winning the 1981 British Formula 3 Championship. His autobiography, "Crash. Burn. Love." details his racing career.

name: Toni Branca
paragraph: Toni Branca (1916 – 1992) was a Swiss Formula One driver who participated in 3 World Championship Grands Prix in 1950 and 1951 for Maserati and Simca-Gordini. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 10th. Branca's racing career was relatively short-lived, with his last F1 appearance being the 1951 German Grand Prix.

name: Toni Ulmen
paragraph: Toni Ulmen (1906 – 1976) was a German racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 (German and Swiss Grands Prix) for Veritas and AFM. He scored no championship points, with a best finish of 8th. Ulmen also took part in several non-championship events and was a veteran of German motorsport in the post-war era.

name: Tony Bettenhausen
paragraph: Tony Bettenhausen (1916 – 1961) was an American racing driver who competed in 12 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1950 and 1960. He achieved 3 podium finishes, including a second place at the 1951 Indianapolis 500, scoring a total of 18 championship points. Bettenhausen was a highly respected IndyCar driver and a national champion. Tragically, he died in a testing crash in 1961.

name: Tony Brise
paragraph: Tony Brise (1952 – 1975) was a British Formula One driver who competed in 10 Grands Prix in the 1975 season for Embassy Hill. He scored 8 championship points, with a best finish of 6th four times. Brise showed immense promise in his short F1 career and was seen as a future star. Tragically, his life was cut short in a plane crash with team owner Graham Hill in November 1975, just weeks after his final F1 Grand Prix.

name: Tony Brooks
paragraph: Tony Brooks (1932 – 2022) was a British Formula 1 driver who competed in 38 Grands Prix from 1956 to 1961 for teams like Connaught, Vanwall, Ferrari, and BRM. He achieved 6 Grand Prix victories and 10 podium finishes, scoring 75 championship points. Brooks was a strong contender for the 1959 World Championship and was known for his smooth, precise driving style, earning him the nickname "The Racing Dentist."

name: Tony Crook
paragraph: Tony Crook (1920 – 2014) was a British racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 and 1953, driving a Frazer Nash. He failed to score any championship points. Crook's F1 career was brief and he was primarily known as a prominent car dealer and later the owner of Bristol Cars. He passed away at the age of 93.

name: Tony Gaze
paragraph: Tony Gaze (1920 – 2013) was an Australian fighter pilot and Formula One driver who competed in 4 Grands Prix in 1952 for HWM. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 15th. Gaze was a decorated war hero, having served in the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II. He is considered one of the pioneering Australian drivers in Grand Prix racing. He passed away at the age of 93.

name: Tony Maggs
paragraph: Tony Maggs (1937 – 2009) was a South African Formula One driver who competed in 25 Grands Prix from 1961 to 1965 for Cooper and BRM. He scored 26 championship points and achieved three podium finishes. Maggs was known for his promising speed and reliability, and was a key figure in the development of the Cooper F1 cars in the early 1960s. He later retired from racing to focus on business interests.

name: Tony Marsh
paragraph: Tony Marsh (1931 – 2009) was a British racing driver who competed in 4 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1957 and 1961. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 15th. Marsh was more successful in British hillclimb racing, winning the British Hillclimb Championship multiple times. His F1 appearances were primarily with privateer entries.

name: Tony Rolt
paragraph: Tony Rolt (1918 – 2008) was a British racing driver who participated in 3 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1950 and 1955. He scored no championship points. Rolt was more famously known for his success in endurance racing, winning the 1953 24 Hours of Le Mans. He was also a decorated military officer during World War II, escaping from Colditz Castle.

name: Tony Settember
paragraph: Tony Settember (1926 – 2014) was an American racing driver who competed in 7 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1962 and 1963 for Emeryson and Scirocco-Powell. He scored no championship points, with a best finish of 10th. Settember's F1 career was brief, and he was primarily involved in sports car racing before and after his foray into F1.

name: Tony Shelly
paragraph: Tony Shelly (1937 – 1998) was a New Zealand Formula One driver who competed in 3 World Championship Grands Prix in 1962 for Lotus and Lola. He failed to score any championship points. Shelly's F1 career was marked by uncompetitive machinery and limited appearances, but he was a successful privateer racer in his native New Zealand and other Tasman Series events.

name: Tony Trimmer
paragraph: Tony Trimmer (born 1943) is a British former racing driver who attempted to qualify for 6 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix between 1975 and 1978 for Maki and Surtees. He famously never managed to qualify for a Grand Prix. Despite his lack of F1 race starts, Trimmer had a highly successful career in other formulae, including winning the British Formula 3 Championship twice and the Aurora F1 Championship.

name: Toranosuke Takagi
paragraph: Toranosuke Takagi (born 1974) is a Japanese former Formula 1 driver who competed in 32 Grands Prix from 1998 to 1999 for Tyrrell and Arrows. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 7th. Takagi was known for his raw speed but often struggled with consistency. After F1, he found significant success in Japanese open-wheel championships like Formula Nippon and the American CART series.

name: Torsten Palm
paragraph: Torsten Palm (born 1947) is a Swedish former racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1975 for Hesketh. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 10th. Palm's racing career was brief, and he was primarily active in Formula 2 and other European racing series before his short foray into F1.

name: Toshio Suzuki
paragraph: Toshio Suzuki (born 1955) is a Japanese former racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1993 for the Larrousse team. He finished 12th in both races and failed to score any championship points. Suzuki is more prominently known for his extensive and successful career in Japanese endurance and sports car racing, including multiple wins in Super GT.

name: Trevor Blokdyk
paragraph: Trevor Blokdyk (1935 – 1995) was a South African Formula One driver who participated in 2 World Championship Grands Prix (1963 and 1965 South African Grands Prix). He failed to score any championship points. Blokdyk competed in various other racing series, including Formula Junior and the South African national championships, where he achieved greater success before his brief foray into F1.

name: Trevor Taylor
paragraph: Trevor Taylor (1936 – 2010) was a British Formula One driver who competed in 27 Grands Prix from 1961 to 1964 for Lotus and BRP. He scored 8 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a second place at the 1962 British Grand Prix. Taylor was known for his speed and was briefly a highly rated talent, but his career was affected by several serious accidents and a lack of consistency.

name: Troy Ruttman
paragraph: Troy Ruttman (1930 – 1997) was an American racing driver who competed in 9 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1950 and 1960. He won the 1952 Indianapolis 500, scoring 8 championship points, and becoming the youngest winner of the event at 22 years old at the time. Ruttman's IndyCar career was marked by his speed and consistency, earning him multiple top-five finishes.

name: Ukyo Katayama
paragraph: Ukyo Katayama (born 1963) is a Japanese former Formula 1 driver who competed in 95 Grands Prix from 1992 to 1997 for Fondmetal, Tyrrell, and Minardi. He scored 5 championship points, with a best finish of 5th. Known for his aggressive driving style, he earned the nickname "The Snake." Despite limited F1 success, Katayama later found success in sports car racing and became a prominent mountaineer.

name: Umberto Maglioli
paragraph: Umberto Maglioli (1928 – 1999) was an Italian Formula One driver who participated in 10 World Championship Grands Prix between 1953 and 1957 for Ferrari and Maserati. He scored 3.33 championship points and achieved two podium finishes, both third places. Maglioli is also highly renowned for his endurance racing accomplishments, including multiple wins at the Targa Florio and a second place at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

name: Valtteri Bottas
paragraph: Valtteri Bottas (born 1989) is a Finnish Formula 1 driver who has competed in 244 Grands Prix (as of June 2025). He has achieved 10 Grand Prix victories and 67 podium finishes, scoring 1167 championship points. Bottas has driven for Williams and Mercedes, before joining Sauber (now Kick Sauber) in 2022. Known for his consistent performances and smooth driving style, he was a key supporting driver during Mercedes' dominant era.

name: Vern Schuppan
paragraph: Vern Schuppan (born 1943) is a retired Australian Formula 1 driver who competed in 9 Grands Prix between 1972 and 1977 for BRM, Ensign, and Surtees. He scored 1 championship point with a 6th place at the 1977 German Grand Prix. Schuppan is best known for his endurance racing achievements, including winning the 1983 24 Hours of Le Mans overall, making him one of Australia's most successful sports car racers.

name: Vic Elford
paragraph: Vic Elford (1935 – 2022) was a British Formula One driver who competed in 13 Grands Prix between 1968 and 1971 for Cooper, McLaren, and BRM. He scored 8 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a fourth place at the 1968 French Grand Prix. Elford was renowned for his versatility, excelling in rallying and sports car racing, winning the 1968 Monte Carlo Rally and the 1968 24 Hours of Daytona. He was a true all-rounder in motorsport.

name: Vic Wilson
paragraph: Vic Wilson (1931 – 2008) was a British racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1966 Belgian Grand Prix, in a BRM, where he retired. He failed to score any championship points. Wilson also competed in non-championship Formula One events and other British national racing series, but his F1 career was brief and without notable success.

name: Victor Martins
paragraph: Victor Martins (born 2001) is a French professional racing driver who is currently competing in the FIA Formula 2 Championship. He is a member of the Alpine Academy (formerly Renault Sport Academy). While he is considered a promising young talent and has participated in F1 test sessions, he has not yet made a Grand Prix start. Martins won the 2022 FIA Formula 3 Championship and is known for his aggressive driving style and ability to perform under pressure.

name: Vincenzo Sospiri
paragraph: Vincenzo Sospiri (born 1966) is a former Italian Formula One driver who attempted to qualify for one Grand Prix, the 1997 Australian Grand Prix, with the Lola team, but the team withdrew after the race. He therefore made no Grand Prix starts. Prior to his unfulfilled F1 career, Sospiri had success in junior formulae, winning the 1995 International Formula 3000 Championship. He later achieved success in sports car racing.

name: Vitaly Petrov
paragraph: Vitaly Petrov (born 1984) is a Russian former Formula One driver who competed in 57 Grands Prix from 2010 to 2012 for Renault and Caterham. He scored 64 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 2011 Australian Grand Prix. Petrov is considered a pioneer for Russian motorsport, being the country's first Formula One driver. He later competed in endurance racing, winning the 2015 FIA World Endurance Championship in class.

name: Vitantonio Liuzzi
paragraph: Vitantonio "Vitto" Liuzzi (born 1980) is a former Italian Formula One driver who competed in 80 Grands Prix from 2005 to 2011 for Red Bull, Toro Rosso, Force India, and HRT. He scored 26 championship points, with a best finish of 6th. Liuzzi was known for his karting prowess and his energetic driving style. He later competed in Super Formula, Formula E, and sports car racing.

name: Vittorio Brambilla
paragraph: Vittorio Brambilla (1937 – 2001) was an Italian Formula 1 driver who competed in 74 Grands Prix from 1974 to 1980 for March and Surtees. He scored 15 championship points and achieved one Grand Prix victory at the rain-soaked 1975 Austrian Grand Prix. Nicknamed "The Monza Gorilla" for his aggressive driving, Brambilla was known for his flamboyant style and ability to extract performance in difficult conditions.

name: Volker Weidler
paragraph: Volker Weidler (born 1962) is a retired German racing driver who attempted to qualify for 10 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1989 for Rial. He famously failed to pre-qualify for any of his entries, thus making no Grand Prix starts. Weidler later found significant success in endurance racing, winning the 1991 24 Hours of Le Mans overall for Mazda. His F1 career was brief and unfulfilled.

name: Walt Ader
paragraph: Walt Ader (1913 – 1982) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1950 Indianapolis 500, where he finished 22nd. He did not score any championship points. Ader's F1 involvement was limited to this single event during the period when the Indianapolis 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship, and he was primarily active in American Championship Car racing.

name: Walt Brown
paragraph: Walt Brown (1911 – 1951) was an American racing driver who competed in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, both of which were the Indianapolis 500 (1950 and 1951). He retired from both races and scored no championship points. Brown was a veteran of American open-wheel racing, and his F1 involvement was limited to these events during the period when the Indianapolis 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship.

name: Walt Faulkner
paragraph: Walt Faulkner (1920 – 1956) was an American racing driver who competed in 6 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, all of which were the Indianapolis 500 between 1950 and 1955. He scored 1 championship point, with a best finish of 5th at the 1950 Indianapolis 500. Faulkner is best known for being the first rookie to start from pole position at the Indianapolis 500 in 1950. He tragically died in a testing crash in 1956.

name: Walt Hansgen
paragraph: Walt Hansgen (1919 – 1966) was an American racing driver who competed in 2 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 1961 and 1964 for Cooper. He scored 2 championship points with a 5th place at the 1964 United States Grand Prix. Hansgen was more famously known for his success in sports car racing, winning multiple SCCA National Championships and the 1961 12 Hours of Sebring. He tragically died in a testing crash in 1966.

name: Warwick Brown
paragraph: Warwick Brown (born 1949) is a former Australian racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1976 United States Grand Prix, for Wolf-Williams, where he retired. He failed to score any championship points. Despite his limited F1 career, Brown had a successful stint in other racing series, including winning the 1975 Tasman Series and the 1977 Australian Grand Prix (a non-championship F1 race).

name: Wayne Weiler
paragraph: Wayne Weiler (1934 – 2005) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1960 Indianapolis 500. He retired from the race and did not score any championship points. Weiler was primarily an IndyCar driver, known for his performances in the USAC Championship Car series during the late 1950s and early 1960s.

name: Will Stevens
paragraph: Will Stevens (born 1991) is a British former Formula 1 driver who competed in 18 Grands Prix from 2014 to 2015 for Caterham and Marussia. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 13th. Stevens later achieved significant success in endurance racing, winning the 2017 FIA World Endurance Championship in the GTE Am class and the 2022 24 Hours of Le Mans in the GTE Pro class.

name: Willi Heeks
paragraph: Willi Heeks (1922 – 1996) was a German Formula One driver who participated in 2 World Championship Grands Prix in 1952 and 1953 for AFM and Veritas. He failed to score any championship points, with a best finish of 11th. Heeks was a relatively unknown driver in the F1 paddock, and his career was brief, primarily focused on national German sports car events.

name: Willi Krakau
paragraph: Willi Krakau (1911 – 1995) was a German racing driver who was entered for one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1952 German Grand Prix, in a BMW. However, he did not start the race and therefore scored no points. Krakau was primarily active in national sports car racing in Germany during the 1950s.

name: William Ferguson
paragraph: William Ferguson (1908 – 1998) was an American racing driver who competed in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1950 Indianapolis 500. He failed to finish the race and did not score any championship points. His F1 involvement was limited to this single event during the period when the Indianapolis 500 counted towards the F1 World Championship.

name: Willy Mairesse
paragraph: Willy Mairesse (1928 – 1969) was a Belgian Formula One driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix from 1956 to 1965 for Ferrari, Cooper, and BRM. He scored 7 championship points and achieved one podium finish, a third place at the 1960 Belgian Grand Prix. Mairesse was known for his aggressive driving style, but his career was cut short due to a serious crash in the 1968 24 Hours of Le Mans, leading to severe depression. He tragically died by suicide in 1969.

name: Wilson Fittipaldi
paragraph: Wilson Fittipaldi (1943 – 2024) was a Brazilian former Formula One driver who competed in 35 Grands Prix from 1972 to 1975 for Brabham and Copersucar. He scored 3 championship points, with a best finish of 5th. He was the older brother of two-time F1 World Champion Emerson Fittipaldi and founded the Fittipaldi F1 team, the only Brazilian constructor in F1 history. He later became a successful businessman and team principal.

name: Wolfgang Seidel
paragraph: Wolfgang Seidel (1926 – 1980) was a German Formula One driver who competed in 12 Grands Prix between 1953 and 1962 for Veritas, Maserati, and Lotus. He failed to score any championship points. Seidel also competed in numerous non-championship events and was a regular privateer entrant in F1 during the 1950s and early 1960s. He was primarily active in sports car racing.

name: Wolfgang von Trips
paragraph: Wolfgang von Trips (1928 – 1961) was a German Formula One driver who competed in 27 Grands Prix from 1956 to 1961 for Ferrari. He achieved 2 Grand Prix victories and 6 podium finishes, scoring 56 championship points. Von Trips was leading the 1961 World Championship when he tragically lost his life in a multi-car crash at the 1961 Italian Grand Prix. His death was a significant loss to F1 and led to increased safety measures.

name: Xavier Perrot
paragraph: Xavier Perrot (1932 – 2009) was a Swiss racing driver who participated in one Formula One World Championship Grand Prix, the 1969 German Grand Prix, driving a Brabham. He failed to qualify for the race and did not score any points. Perrot was primarily active in European Formula 2 racing. His F1 career was very brief, limited to this single attempt.

name: Yannick Dalmas
paragraph: Yannick Dalmas (born 1961) is a French former Formula One driver who competed in 24 Grands Prix from 1987 to 1990 for Larrousse and AGS. He failed to score any championship points. Despite his limited F1 success, Dalmas achieved significant success in endurance racing, winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans overall four times (1992, 1994, 1995, 1999), making him one of the most successful drivers in Le Mans history.

name: Yuji Ide
paragraph: Yuji Ide (born 1975) is a Japanese former racing driver who competed in 4 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix in 2006 for the Super Aguri team. Due to concerns over his performance and safety, he had his superlicence revoked and did not complete the season, scoring no points. Ide was primarily active in Japanese junior formulae before his brief and controversial F1 stint.

name: Yuki Tsunoda
paragraph: Yuki Tsunoda (born 2000) is a Japanese Formula 1 driver who currently competes for the RB Formula 1 Team (formerly AlphaTauri). He made his F1 debut in 2021 and has since made 87 Grand Prix starts (as of June 2025), scoring 76 championship points. Tsunoda has impressed with his speed, aggressive driving style, and strong race craft, establishing himself as a tenacious and promising talent in the F1 paddock.

name: Yves Giraud-Cabantous
paragraph: Yves Giraud-Cabantous (1904 – 1973) was a French racing driver who competed in 13 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix from 1950 to 1953 for Talbot-Lago and HWM. He scored 3 championship points, achieving a best finish of 4th at the inaugural 1950 British Grand Prix. Cabantous was a veteran of Grand Prix racing before the official F1 World Championship began, and was known for his versatile driving skills.

name: Zak O'Sullivan
paragraph: Zak O'Sullivan (born 2005) is a British racing driver currently competing in the FIA Formula 2 Championship. He is a member of the Williams Driver Academy and has participated in Formula 1 free practice sessions for the team, but has not yet made a Grand Prix start. O'Sullivan has shown promising skills and speed throughout his junior career, winning the 2021 GB3 Championship and finishing runner-up in the 2023 FIA Formula 3 Championship, marking him as a strong contender for future F1 opportunities.

name: Zsolt Baumgartner
paragraph: Zsolt Baumgartner (born 1981) is a Hungarian former Formula One driver who competed in 20 Grands Prix in 2003 and 2004 for Jordan and Minardi. He scored 1 championship point with an 8th-place finish at the 2004 United States Grand Prix. Baumgartner remains the only Hungarian driver to have competed in Formula One, and his career was characterized by perseverance despite limited resources.
